reviews.review_text: I was quite drawn to 10,000,000 because of the promise it showed in mixing RPG and puzzle elements. While the game delivered less depth than the concept seemed to allow for, I still got a very fast-paced, addictive, and satisfying puzzler. It was cumbersome using a mouse to play a game that was clearly designed with touch screens in mind, but the gameplay was enjoyable enough at its core to ease that pain most of the time. The music was catchy, and the variety of things to level up provided enough incentive to make it through most of the game. What I most appreciated was the fact that you're unlikely to brute force your way to the 10,000,000 point goal by simply grinding enough to level everything. Success is ultimately the result of strategy, speed, and good fortune, which was refreshing after the way so many other smartphone ports that have made it to this platform just hand victory to the player after a significant enough investment of time and virtual currency. It's unlikely that you'll want to revisit this one after beating it, but the asking price is very reasonable for a game of 10,000,000's overall quality.

10,000,000. An RPGish, Bejeweled-like game. Well... ok...  While the game does have an interesting concept it annoyingly relies on luck and what tiles the game decides to generate more than anything else, much like Bejeweled or similar puzzle games. If a monster is in your path, you'll have to quickly match sword or staff tiles to do damage. A locked chest requires matching key tiles. And as tiles are random, one might find oneself stuck, matching any tiles at all, hoping to match enough of what is needed before time is up.  At the start of the game, be prepared to lose, quite often, until enough materials are gathered to unlock upgrades. While initially the upgrades that can be purchased come in handy and allow one to make quick work of monsters, the upgrades have a max level which in my opinion is too low. Especially during the latter ranks, and especially when fighting bosses. Even completely maxed out requires, more often than not, way too many tile matches and wastes way too much time. However, there are items to find thru out the dungeon run which can help somewhat. Scrolls that will change wood or stone tiles to keys, swords, or staves. Various weapons and orbs to hurl at monsters. Skeleton keys to easily unlock chests or locks. And food items that will give you a time boost. With that said, the weapons, orbs and skeleton keys must be used rather precisely; if used a split second too early when arriving upon a chest or monster the item does nothing and disappears. The same can be said for tiles too. It would have been nice if there was some leeway as making sure the dungeon runner is close enough to an obstacle before using items can waste valuable time, even if just a split second.  And possibly the biggest time waster in the game, combos. Match some tiles, more fall down and they match. Combo! They are sometimes handy like during a boss fight. Except when the tiles continue to fall and continue to match it becomes a potential death trap. Yes, I've lost more than once awaiting tiles to stop falling and matching others because during this time nothing else can be done. And if the reason I lost wasn't because I ran out of time, it was shortly after because the combo completely used up tiles that would have came in handy just a few seconds later.  Replay value? Prepare to spend several hours upgrading everything before even attempting a run for 10,000,000. But after one does achieve freedom by getting to a score of 10,000,000, the only reason I can think of to come back to this game would be to try for a higher personal score (no Steam leaderboards), or to earn all achievements. Personally, once I complete all the achievements I doubt I will ever play this again.  Is 10,000,000 fun? Sure, it can be. Would I recommend it? Hmm. Not at the full price of $4.99. I picked it up on sale for less than a dollar. At that price it was worth it. While I don't really want to vote thumbs down, I'm going to have to since Steam has no neutral option.

OVER 10,000,000! Yes, that is the goal of this game.   Even though the concept of match-3 puzzle have been use hundreds of time, the addition of RPG and action element make this game stand above all. There is also material tiles, after every run end, you gain the materials and experience points to help strengthen your charactor, which help you on the next run.  Unlike the mobile counterpart, the PC port does not feel like endless at all. Once you upgrade everything to the max, which is fairly easy grind, and reach 10,000,000, the game feel finish because of lack of a leaderboard. I must note that the achievement does add extra challenge but once you get use to the control, you shouldn't have problem clearing them.  Overall, I must say this game is a good buy for the listing price, can even be a must buy when it on sale. You may want to play this game on your phone though, is it a phone game afterall.

A relatively simple match-3 style game where you match tiles to execute various commands while adventuring through a linear dungeon hallway: attack, block, magic, get item, use key (for doors and treasure chests), and a few resource gathering things. Get cash, XP, and resources, upgrade your character, and repeat. Get a score of 10,000,000 to beat the game. Nowhere near as forgiving as something like Bejeweled, but the hallway really just boils down to a timer mechanic that forces you to match certain types of tiles in order to add time to your game.  Worth skipping a soda with lunch to buy, but not enough here to recommend further.

The tiles you match on the board causes your character to perform an action - locked door in your way? Match key tiles to unlock it! Generic bad guy attacking you? Sword his ♥♥♥ or magic his face in by matching sword or rod tiles! It goes deeper than that, but just that alone make it totally worth the low price it is selling for right now. If you're into really fast paced action, get this thing!

Achievement completion at time of writing: 100%  This is a port of the mobile game of the same name. It is a match 3 game where you either slide a row or a column to make matches for whatever is needed at the time. Locked Doors and Chests require keys, Monsters require Swords and Staves, Shields are used for defense, Stars for items to help, and Stone and Wood for building your home base afterwards.  The objective is to go as far as you can in a dungeon, and upon failure you take all the resources you gathered to upgrade your home base to allow even further runs. The main goal is to have a total score of over 10,000,000 in one run of a dungeon.  It's fun for a few hours, though the game is pretty short. If you can get it cheap, it'll be good value.

A combination of tile matching and dungeon running, it takes pieces of different game styles, mashes them together, and lobs them at your head. Not only are you matching tiles to defeat monsters, open doors and unlock treasure chests, but you have missions to accomplish in order to advance and upgrade your equipment. Sometimes they come easy, sometimes you want to grab the little Indiana Jones look-alike by his 8-bit feet and swing him around, screaming 'RUN FASTER, &#@%&!* YOU!!!'

Addicting. SO. VERY. ADDICTING. A combination of RPG and match three. Oh, but there's a twist: instead of moving pieces, you move the columns and lines of pieces to make the matches and defeat your enemies. If you are into fast paced puzzle games, 10,000,000 is for you.

So to start off my review I award this game with the 'broke me of going after achievements' award.  The game is a simple puzzle sliding game with rpg elements thrown in. Very rarely do I 'want' to like a game more than I do this one. The style's fun, matching games in general are addictive, and I really do want to keep progressing. But the balance feels wrong and much more often than not the game really frustrates someone just looking for a good time. It's a matching game but if you're not matching the blocks you're supposed to be matching to defeat a monster or unlock a chest or whatever the game is throwing at you, then you die. And you die pretty quickly at that. You can go from full health on a great run to dead in just a few seconds if you haven't matched the tiles that you need. Most of the time you can't find the blocks you need at any given moment, without having cleared other tiles first. The game simply has one block type too many obstructing combo flow. Two of the seven block types have no function in the dungeon crawl except to impede your progress, at any given enemy encounter only two of the blocks might be useful to you. With less than half of the screen being useful and enemies eating your time you'll frequently die in less time it takes to read this review.  It wouldn't be so bad if it gave you more time to plan combo chains. Or maybe you could stockpile matched blocks so that items like keys would stay in your invetory for unlocking doors and chests. Instead you can only match blocks at the moment you need them with previous matches disappearing uselessly. Mind you, it has to be at the very moment you need them, if you make the match too fast before the character runs up to the encounter, it also doesn't count wasting valuable blocks.  If you somehow ended up becoming a master genius at the game, or if you've grinded enough hours to buy enough perks, it could be great. But the early stages are just no fun and only succeeded in frustrating me. After a while I lose interest in mastery. The game just feels too unfair.

Well well well, where to start with this game?  Awhile back I heard about 10,000,000 and I was looking forward to getting my hands on it to play, after I got it, I spent 2 or 3 hours playing it nonstop, soon after my play session ended I relised I felt really weird, so I tryed to stand up, and I felt so disorentated dizzy to almost the point where I felt intoxicated, I couldnt understand it.  That aside, the time spent playing 10,000,000 has had its frustraitons, but it was very fun, what ever it may be, getting huge combos going, to the silly hints, everything about it brings such a retro feel, the music and audio compliments the game.  In a nutshell, the top side scroller looking area of the screen is a cleverly disguised timer and health bar. Your character runs through a dungeon, and all of his actions are controlled by the blocks you match. Need to unlock a door or a chest? Match some keys. A monster blocking your path? Physical attacks are executed by matching swords while magical attacks fire off by matching staves. Standing still by not matching causes the timer to tick down, pushing your character to the left, and getting hit by monsters also pushes you to the left. The damage aspect can be mitigated by matching shields, which are absorbed instead of pushing your character. Fall off the side of the screen and it's game over.  To supplement these mechanics are a set of shockingly deep loot, item, upgrade, and experience systems. Monsters can drop loot, and you can also get loot by matching backpack tiles or unlocking chests. Loot can either be gold to buy upgrades or actual usable items. A few items you'll come across are a red orb that'll damage whatever monster is in front of you, a key to instantly unlock a chest or doorway blocking your path, scrolls to spawn more tiles of a certain type on the board, and much more.  Every time you start up your game and get ready to explore, your character lierally Jumps out of bed and is ready to rock, I first noticed the score and the goal, which reminded me of one of those Awful motivation posters that were en vogue in the 90's and acts like one too.  You really need to think about the games mechanics, because 10000000 doesn't tell you much beyond the qwerky loading hits, and leave you on your own to explore, I find that this works perfecly with short playt sessions, and adds a sense of discovery that I found fun.  If you have one of your 10,000,000 runs that lasts more than a minute or two you are doing considerably well, it gives you a chance to catch your breath and break down what you learned during your last attempt to reach your goal of 10,000,000.  This is a game with a protestant work, and you have to Aceept failure as part of the Journey, and try your best to do a little better every time.  I have really enjoyed my time so far playing 10,000,000 and I hope everyone else can have some fun with it too.  I would rate 10,000,000 a:    4 out of 5  As it does what its intended too exactly as it should.

Although it has a lot of things going against it (Match 3 puzzle game, iOS port, etc) this game is loads of fun. Don't be fooled by the store page, this isn't actually an RPG, but simply a match-3 puzzler with RPG elements.   While most M3 games have you moving one symbol around in one of 4 directions, this one has you rotating columns/rows to match 3. It takes a bit of getting used to, but well worth it.   Most gameplay is spent on the dungeon crawling. You look up on the screen, and match the symbol needed above. eg: If theres a chest, match 3 key symbols.  You cannot pass until you match the correct symbol, and theres an advancing wall that kills you (Keep ahead of it!). There are also monsters that you must kill using either Magic or Physical matches (Different monsters have different weaknesses). There are different items you can use too. Overall, a great timewaster/puzzler, but not really a puzzler.   17/20

10 ♥♥♥♥ing million. That's the score you need to get to beat the game. And that's all you gotta do...  ...I might be oversimplifying things a little bit, since it will take you a good couple of hours to beat it (around 7-8h).  The game is very easy to understand, you have a guy running on your screen and once you get an obstacle, you have to take care of it. If you have a door, you will have to combine 4 keys, if you have an enemy you can either combine swords or staves. The idea is to never fall behind or you lose.  Once you reach preset milestones, you will have the option to play harder levels, that rewards you with higher score multipliers. The higher the level, the higher the score you will get, and the harder the monsters are.  This is a game where you will fail 99.9% of the time, and once you get that 10,000,000 score you are likely not to touch this game again, but it's so extremely addictive and at the same time frustrating. After each attempt you can spend your resources (wood, stone and experience) on power ups that will help you get through the levels...  Pros: - Very addictive - Decent RPG elements  Cons:  - Music - Story... or lack of. - Price, the mobile version of this game is much cheaper...  7/10

It's fine as long as you aren't expecting too much. You frantically match-3 until you die, trying to complete the tasks you're faced with by matching specific tiles (e.g. unlocking chests with key tiles). You also collect resources tiles while you play and use them to upgrade everything after each game. It's a little annoying that you simply can't progress very far until you get enough upgrades no matter how well you play, but it adds to the addictiveness of the game, to complete everything.

3 Match, action packed, Something?  The game is great in the 3-matching concept, killing monsters as you match, the feeling of acheivement at the end of a long run is really good. But I do not understand the story behind the game.  To me the game could have done better in the story department, but where it lacks in that it picks up in the 3 - match.  7/10

It was 9 hours of grinding for me to (almost) 100% this game, and I really mean grinding ― actually quite unpleasant in the middle, when you're too far into the game to deal with cheap upgrades, but still too weak to be able to farm resources easily. My impression is that 10,000,000 relies too much on luck, and is a little too fast; you don't have enough time to think and are just relying on intuition and quick matching. Sometimes it just made me want to play Puzzle Quest instead. Still, I guess it's alright to kill some time, although it's probably better on a mobile device.  PS. If you want my advice for this game, never don't be matching.
